thread.title: Google Fiber at last? Portland begins fielding applications for 'fiber huts'
thread.title_full: Google Fiber at last? Portland begins fielding applications for 'fiber huts' | OregonLive.com

author: Mike Rogoway | The Oregonian/OregonLive
title: Google Fiber at last? Portland begins fielding applications for 'fiber huts'
text:
Google Fiber has played coy for nearly 20 months, but the gig may finally be up.
Portland is set to review applications next week for Google "fiber huts" at seven locations around the city, indications the company is preparing to begin building its hyperfast communications network.
Since February 2014, Google Fiber has been very publicly deliberating whether to offer service in Portland. It's begun building high-capacity in other cities on its possible expansion list, but not on the far West, where Portland and two other cities (San Jose and Phoenix) were left hanging.
Google declined comment on the fiber huts. Mary Beth Henry, director of Portland's Office of Community Technology, cautioned the filings do not represent a "firm commitment" by the company.
Nonetheless, the applications are a clear sign it's actively planning a Portland network and preparing to begin construction.
The fiber huts are approximately 12 feet by 30 feet, and 9 feet high, according to applications submitted to the city on Google's behalf. Each would sit behind a 10-foot fence. (See pictures above of fiber huts in Google Fiber's first market, Kansas City.)
They house equipment for the network, a hub for thousands of fiber's passing from Google's main lines to smaller utility cabinets along city streets that will distribute Internet traffic to individual homes.
The land-use applications state the huts can service up to 40,000 homes apiece. That's double the number Google said they could handle last year, when Portland approved a framework agreement for the company to lease city property for the huts.
The seven proposed fiber huts are distributed across the city, from St. Johns to outer Southeast Portland, and suggest that Google is eyeing nearly every part of the city. It determines specific areas for service based on the number of households in a given neighborhood who sign up.
A Kansas engineering company called BHC Rhodes submitted the applications on Google Fiber's behalf. The company has also done work for Google in other cities, including Austin, where Google Fiber is launching a network.
Google Fiber offers Internet connections at 1 gigabit per second, 40 times faster than the current broadband standard. The company hopes faster Internet access will enable new online applications, and new businesses for Google to pursue.
Since the company announced last year that Portland is a possible expansion city, Frontier Communications and CenturyLink have each begun offering their own gigabit service in parts of the Portland area and Comcast says it's planning its own gigabit service, too.
Google charges $70 a month for gigabit connections, and another $65 for an accompanying cable TV service. That's in line with comparable services from established companies, though others often impose higher rates after an initial trial period.
Google Fiber is also considering service in Gresham, Tigard, Lake Oswego, Beaverton, Hillsboro and parts of unincorporated Washington County.
